Using an LLM to revamp my site

Truth, lies, and life in The True Deceiver

My favorite book is The True Deceiver by Tove Jansson, famed creator of the Moomin comics. It was published in 1982 (late in Jansson‚Äôs life; she started creating the Moomin comics in the 1940s) and released in English in 2009.

17 Feb 2025

Finally reading The Count of Monte Cristo

I bought a copy of The Count of Monte Cristo from my local Half Price Books when I was in high school. It remained on my shelf for all of high school, and I donated it (probably back to Half Price Books) when I went to college. Last month, over 15 years after I first bought the book, I finally read The Count of Monte Cristo. My first impression of the book was that it was boring. I thought it would be a lot more swashbuckling than it was ‚Äì a tale of revenge! Perhaps I was also mixing up The Count of Monte Cristo with the author‚Äôs other famous work, The Three Musketeers. Even though I had a hard time getting into the book, once I was in it, I loved it. It‚Äôs a slow burn revenge plot ‚Äì scenarios take years (and many chapters) for the Count of Monte Cristo to set up, but the final reveal is always incredible.

#books
27 Jan 2025

Reading Trollope for the first time

After years and years of seeing Trollope books in used bookstores and thinking ‚ÄúI should read those someday,‚Äù I finally read The Claverings in October 2024. I chose this specific book to be my foray into Trollope because it was a standalone book (not part of a larger series like the Chronicles of Barsetshire) and the plot seemed similar to the kind of stuff I already like in Victorian literature (basically, marriage plot with a twist). While I‚Äôm glad I read the book and enjoyed parts of it, I found it overlong and depressingly patriarchal. I‚Äôm honestly surprised by the rave reviews on Goodreads.

Managing library books on the Kobo Libra H2O

This page describes how to set up a library account and manage library books on the Kobo Libra H2O device using OverDrive functionality. This page does not cover the Kobo app, another tool you can use to check out books to both the app and your e-reader.

08 Dec 2024

A disappointing dnf

I was excited to read Welcome to the Hyunam-Dong Bookshop because I thought the premise (woman quits high-stress job to run a bookshop) was fun and cute. It took me two weeks to read the first 60 pages before I decided to call it quits. I‚Äôve read reviews that call Welcome to the Hyunam-Dong Bookshop ‚Äúcomforting‚Äù and ‚Äúgentle‚Äù but I just found it boring. Everything felt too long, too clique, and too general. I read some reviews that mention that the characters‚Äô backstories are revealed later. I‚Äôve read books where that progressive revelation really works, but here I just wasn‚Äôt compelled enough to stick around for the reveal.

#books
08 Dec 2024

A great setup and disappointing payoff in Admission

I recently read Admission by Jean Hanff Korelitz. It‚Äôs my third book by Korelitz; I‚Äôve also read The Latecomer and The Plot. Both of these books feel like the best kind of literary fiction ‚Äì they‚Äôre long, but not just long. They‚Äôre expansive but not overlong, long enough so I can really relax and revel in the story, but not boring at all. They take their time building up the circumstances and plot, and going into the backstories of characters, and then things start to unravel and build and it‚Äôs great! I found both of these books so satisfying to read and expected something similar from Admission.

I read the New York Times‚Äôs new list of best books of the 21st century and I definitely shouldn‚Äôt have read it right before going to bed because it got me worked up. I can‚Äôt believe that some of my favorite books and authors aren‚Äôt on the list. I‚Äôm frustrated that some books that I think are way overrated made the list.

03 Jul 2024

Leaving fairyland behind: on rereading books from my childhood

I reread books a lot. The mark of a good book, in my opinion, is one that I know I will reread. Rereading is a weird thing, though ‚Äì sometimes I reread a book and I love it so much more than I did initially (examples: Pride and Prejudice, Wuthering Heights). Sometimes it‚Äôs more gradual, and each time I reread a book I like it more and more (examples: The True Deceiver, Free Food for Millionaires). But I‚Äôve sometimes had the experience of rereading a book and liking it less than the first time or just feeling like the book didn‚Äôt live up to my memory of it. I felt this way recently about Anne of the Island, the third book in the Anne of Green Gables series. In the book, Anne leaves Prince Edward Island to go to college in Kingsport, Nova Scotia. The book wasn‚Äôt as good as I remembered it being, and I also remembered some key scenes, scenes that were important to my overarching narrative of being A Reader as a child, flat-out wrong.

#books
17 Jun 2024

Reading as a new parent

I had a baby in April and, predictably, barely read anything during the first month. After that, I‚Äôve mostly returned to my typical pace of four books a month. Reading right now looks different than it did before the baby ‚Äì and I expect it will change even more as the baby gets older and more active! For now, though, I‚Äôve shifted to reading on my ereader instead of physical books, and to reading longer books and series instead of shorter books.

In search of a good western book

Ever since I randomly found the book The Whistling Season by Ivan Doig at the Half Price Books closest to my Minnesota hometown, I‚Äôve been on a casual quest to find another ‚Äúwestern‚Äù book that‚Äôs as satisfying.

21 Sep 2022

A beautiful book, you were not

I‚Äôm a little bit embarrassed about how much I like Conversations with Friends and Normal People, the first two books by author Sally Rooney. I think this embarrassment comes from a variety of places. Sally Rooney is a super popular author, and I sort of resent that I really like an author who a lot of other people like. I want to have more alternative, subtle taste in books! Her books are also pretty melodramatic. They‚Äôre all on-and-off relationships and lack of communication and existential crises. I like this angst, but I‚Äôm also a little ashamed that I like this angst ‚Äì it feels like something I should have grown out of. Anyway, because I liked Sally Rooney‚Äôs first two books so much, I was really excited to hear she had a new book coming out ‚Äì Beautiful World, Where Are You. I was so excited in fact, that I preordered the damn book back in June. (It came out in September.) I‚Äôve never preordered a book in my life.

24 Jul 2022

Some thoughts about the books I read in May and June 2022

The worst book I read recently was Lady Chatterley‚Äôs Lover, which provoked a landmark obscenity trial in the UK in 1960. Some critics think D.H. Lawrence‚Äôs writing style was influenced by his tuberculosis, which he died from two years after publishing Lady Chatterley‚Äôs Lover. Apparently, tuberculosis can cause a heightened emotional state and also impotence, which matches up pretty well to my personal beef with the book: I found the prose insufferably flowery and the characters flat and annoying.

#books #recaps
20 May 2022

Buy Nothing groups in Mountain View and San Mateo

I moved from Mountain View to San Mateo at the end of March. In anticipation of my move, I joined my Mountain View neighborhood‚Äôs Buy Nothing group in order to offload some of the things that I didn‚Äôt want to pack up and move ‚Äì things like clothes I no longer wore, books I read and didn‚Äôt like, some cheap IKEA furniture that I longer needed, and various items of an old roommate that I‚Äôd never gotten around to getting rid of. The Mountain View Buy Nothing group I joined was extremely active ‚Äì multiple people expressed interest in almost everything I posted, and I was ultimately able to rehome a lot of items. I was surprised how great doing this felt ‚Äì less profit driven than donating to Goodwill, more ‚Äúuseful‚Äù than bringing to the recycling center, more personal than posting on the free section of Craigslist, and more altruistic than selling on eBay (not that I could sell things like miscellaneous light bulbs anyway).

#musings

18 Jan 2022

Kindred didn‚Äôt pander to me

I loved the book The Help when I was in high school ‚Äì it takes place in the 1960s and the protagonist is a white woman who writes about black maids working in white households. It‚Äôs not a terrible book, but it centers on a nice white woman who helps black people (who don‚Äôt really need the help in the first place) and then profits off of it. I liked the book because it was readable and the characters were overall compelling, but even more so, I liked it because it pandered to me, a white reader.

05 Aug 2021

Third-person omniscient narration in Free Food for Millionaires

Min Jin Lee uses third-person omniscient narration in Free Food for Millionaires, a book I read in July and haven‚Äôt been able to stop thinking about. A lot of books use this style ‚Äì Middlemarch and The House of Mirth, for example, both narrate the stories and thoughts of many characters. (Middlemarch is, incidentally or not, Free Food for Millionaires protagonist Casey Han‚Äôs favorite book.)

#books
08 Jul 2021

Don‚Äôt sleep, there are tons of boring linguistic details

I recently finished Don‚Äôt Sleep, There are Snakes: Life and Language in the Amazonian Jungle, an autobiographical account of Daniel Everett‚Äôs time as a Christian missionary to the Piraha (a small Amazon tribe), his analysis of the tribe‚Äôs unique language and linguistic structure, and his subsequent ‚Äúdeconversion.‚Äù There weren‚Äôt a TON of boring linguistic details ‚Äì just a little too much academic theory for me. I thought I was going to read a travelogue/ethnography with a sprinkle of linguistic details. What I got was approximately half that, and half critical theory. But that‚Äôs okay.

I didn‚Äôt like Mexican Gothic, but a lot of critics did

I didn‚Äôt like Mexican Gothic, but a lot of other people did. I was so excited about the premise: a gothic novel in 1950s Mexico! I thought, ‚Äúmaybe this will be sort of like a new twist on Jane Eyre.‚Äù Yeah, it wasn‚Äôt. I was disappointed.

04 Feb 2021

The House of Mirth and The Awakening have so many similarities

I read The House of Mirth and The Awakening almost back to back (one book in between ‚Äì Susan Choi‚Äôs Person of Interest) unintentionally, but I was totally struck by how similar the two books are. The Awakening was published in 1899, while The House of Mirth was published just six years later in 1905. The protagonists, Lily Bart and Edna Pontellier, are also incredibly similar (and, interestingly, almost exactly the same age ‚Äì Edna turns 28 during the course of The Awakening; Lily is 29 when The House of Mirth begins) ‚Äì both are in rather precarious positions because of both their own actions and their own yearnings for something more than conventional social life, and both end their own lives because they are unable to find fulfillment through men and society and unwilling to conceive of a life outside of those constraints.

#books
01 Jan 2021

I like e-readers now

I‚Äôve never been a fan of e-readers. I‚Äôm put off by the prospect of paying for a book that only exists on a device, especially when the price of e-books approaches or exceeds the cost of physical books (especially the used copies I tend to buy). I also just love physical books ‚Äì the weight and feel of them, the experience of reading, the look of books on my shelf.

#books #tech
26 Sep 2020

American Woman considers how radicalism can produce ambivalence

American Woman is a fictionalization of the Patty Hearst kidnapping and aftermath ‚Äì specifically, it focuses on the time between the SLA robbery of a sporting goods store in May 1974 and her arrest in April 1975.

#books
13 Jun 2020

Normal People is about shifting power dynamics, not love

Normal People is about the power dynamics that are present inside and outside of a romantic relationship and how they shift over time (over years and also over moments) because of the relationship itself, external factors, and individual factors like insecurity and mental health.

#books

Elantris is the first book I‚Äôve read by Brandon Sanderson, an author I keep hearing about from a lot of different people.
